issues.title: Add section on Changes from RFCXXXX
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: You only write in the intro that there are significant change but don't give anywhere a summary of what the changes are. For implementor that want to update that specific information would be highly valuable. For this reason bis documents often has a section title "Changes from RFCXXXX" which gives a bullet list of change (and potentially pointers to the specific parts in the doc). I think it would be very useful to have such a section in this doc as well.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I was looking at the wrong version. The editor's copy (https://ingjohericsson.github.io/draft-johansson-ccwg-scream-bis/draft-johansson-ccwg-scream-bis.html) does not seem to be up-to-date. I see now that you have already a list which is great! I guess you can or can't add an own section heading. Also I still recommend to add reference to the respective sections (if possible).

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: I have not yet figured out how to add references in markdown

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
You use {#xxx} to define an anchor and then {{xxx}} to refer to it, e.g.

```
# section 1 {#sec1}

See {{sec1}} for further information.
```

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: #17 added this.

issues.title: Draft name should be draft-johansson-ccwg-rfc8298bis
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: The usual naming for a bis draft would be draft-johansson-ccwg-rfc8298bis. If you want to have scream in the name, I recommend using draft-johansson-ccwg-rfc8298bis-scream.

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: OK. That should then be changed

issues.title: LTE is soo yesterday ;-)
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Does it still make sense to talk about LTE in the draft? I guess we could say it more generally like "mobile networks, like e.g. LTE" or something? I actually wonder if section 1.1. is still needed at all?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: I see now that is this also mostly addressed. I guess we could talk even less about 3GPP but the current text is fine as well.

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: You are probably right. On the other hand I (we) have tried it mainly with 3GPP access (4G and 5G), with only limited testing in WiFi home networks.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: done

issues.title: Using artwork for equations
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
With the v3 xml you can now use artwork for equations e.g. like this

```
~~~ math
\frac{a}{a}
~~~
{: artwork-align="center" }
```

I believe this is align with tex. Maybe see the cubic bis doc for more examples:

https://github.com/NTAP/rfc8312bis/blob/main/draft-ietf-tcpm-rfc8312bis.md?plain=1

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: OK. thanks!

issues.title: Rename the algorithm to SCREAMv2?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Removal of fast increase, making it more rate-based, and the general change of the the delay-based approach, maybe we should actually call this also differently. It's definitely not only a bis where you try to fix some issues. It's really more a redesign. If you still want to obsolete the old scream draft, I propose to call this algorithm SCREAMv2.

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: Yes, it is actually a major redesign. In the github code it named ScreamV2Tx.cpp. I don't have a very strong opinion, which is the preferred, seen from an IETF perspective ?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: This was done

issues.title: Explain increase function in overview slightly better
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
In Section 3.1. (network congestion control):

> The congestion window seeks to increase by at least one segment per RTT and this increase regardless congestion occurs or not, the congestion window increase is restriced or relaxed based on the congestion window and the time elapsed since last congestion event.

I don't think I understand this. Especially what does it mean that "the congestion window increase is restriced or relaxed based on the congestion window..."?

issues.title: Rewrite Section on Receiver Requirements on Feedback Intensity
issues.author: gloinul
issues.body: The current section on  Receiver Requirements on Feedback Intensity is very much written from an RTCP perspective. That RTCP related discussion is useful for protocol with that limitation. However for protocol that allow feedback based on other rules could benefit from a general high level discussion and then protocol specific discussion.

issues.title: Minor nit: Use of the term "compromized"
issues.author: IngJohEricsson
issues.body: "SCReAMv2 compromised several algorithm simplifications and adds support for L4S", the word "compromized" sounds odd in this context

issues.title: Some deviations from running code to be fixed
issues.author: IngJohEricsson
issues.body:
A few good features from the running code on https://github.com/EricssonResearch/scream to be added.

REF_WND_OVERHEAD: defaults to 5.0 in running code. This value should however complemented with a note that recommends a lower value for cases when a media encoder reacts slowly to changes in target bitrate

"Apply limit to reference window growth when close to last known max value before congestion": should be applied also when L4S active, and then both for up and down adjustment of ref_wnd

Increase ref_wnd inhibited when max target bitrate is reached

"limit bitrate if bytes in flight exceeds is close to or exceeds ref_wnd" is applied also when L4S active

pulls.title: Add high-level equations to overview
pulls.author: mirjak
pulls.body:
Proposing this as I thought it might help understand the algorithm on a high level.

However, I'm not fully sure about the decrease part. I added qtarget_alpha, which is not defined yet, because it looks like there is only multiplicative decrease but I have to say the whole target_delay related part is a bit confusing to me right now. Need to double-check!

Further, it could be good to give some more hinds about the increase part as well but not sure how to summarise it easily in one line of pseudo code...

Do it help to add this?

comments.body:
```suggestion
ref_wnd = BETA_LOSS * (BETA_ECN|l4s_alpha) * qtarget_alpha * ref_wnd
```

pulls.title: Edits on the first three sections.
pulls.author: gloinul

comments.author: IngJohEricsson
comments.body: I merge this one, will try with an edit session in a near future
Why "initial congestion avoidance phase"? I think both of these phases are part of congestion avoidance. If we want to name the phase we should come up with new names.
So first "congestion avoidance" might be my missinterpretation here. What does @IngJohEricsson say? Secondly, do we need to coin a term for this phase and explain it better?

Slow (as always).. One can say that the first time after a congestion event is normal additive increase, while the multiplicative increase gradually kicks in the longer time it goes since the congestion event. 
The increase factor is also limited when the reference window is close the last known max value.

reviews.author: gloinul
reviews.body: Two sentence needs fixing before merging.

comments.body: This sentence needs fixing.
"to only help to avoid that" another strange formulation that I don't quite understand.
@IngJohEricsson you will have to take a look and clarify the meaning.
@IngJohEricsson can you please help clarify what is intended to mean.
Yes, I assume we can just remove the "to only help"

```suggestion
 * Target bitrate down adjustment when ref_wnd/mss is small is modified to
   avoid that the data unit queue grows excessively in certain low
```
At minimum there are some nits but this sentence is not super clear.

```suggestion
 * Slow down reference window growth when close to the last known maximum value is disabled
   and when L4S is active. This makes SCReAM adhere more closely to two marked packets
```
Yes, sounds good to remove "to only help"
Fine with me

The feedback from the receiver is assumed to consist of the following elements:
